Problem_statement: Large shares of renewable energy sources create a merit-order effect that reduces the profitability and operation time of conventional power plants.
Research_gap: The impact of long-term variability in wind and hydropower production on the profit stability of conventional plants needs further quantification. (inferred).
Contribution: A model-based analysis assesses how transmission capacity between continental Europe and the Nordic system reduces the long-term variability of plant profits.

Authors: Dideriksen, A. F.; Sekkesater, S.; Fleten, S.; Aasgord, E. K.; Skjelbred, H.
Title: Operational use of marginal cost curves for a hydropower producer trading in the intraday market
Problem_statement: The introduction of intermittent renewables increases system imbalances, requiring hydropower producers to participate effectively in continuous intraday markets to maintain grid stability.
Research_gap: Existing literature either focuses on order placement without dispatch optimization or optimizes dispatch while neglecting the detailed description of continuous market dynamics.
Contribution: A simulation framework for the intraday bidding problem combines optimal order placement with dispatch scheduling to maximize profit in continuous electricity markets.

Authors: Skjelbred, H. I.; Kong, J.; Larsen, T. J.; Kristiansen, F.
Title: Operational use of marginal cost curves for hydropower plants as decision support in real-time balancing markets
Problem_statement: Generating bidding curves for complex cascaded watercourses is computationally demanding and difficult to implement within operational short-term hydropower optimization models like SHOP.
Research_gap: Existing operational models struggle to efficiently calculate marginal cost curves for plants with multiple identical units without suffering from the curse of dimensionality.
Contribution: Three heuristic methods generate bidding curves by simplifying unit combinations and operating points, significantly reducing computation time while maintaining high solution quality.

Authors: Benedikt Hreinsson, E.
Title: Operations modeling in the Iceland hydro dominated power system
Problem_statement: Planning for hydro-dominated systems is complex due to time-interdependence of storage and emerging short-term phenomena like wind variability.
Research_gap: Traditional fixed time frame models struggle to bridge the gap between fast-moving wind resources and slowly moving reservoir dynamics.
Contribution: A dynamic time frame modeling approach adaptively reduces time step size during operational constraint violations to improve the accuracy of hydro-wind integration.

Authors: Steeger, G.; Barroso, L. A.; Rebennack, S.
Title: Optimal Bidding Strategies for Hydro-Electric Producers: A Literature Survey
Problem_statement: Power generation companies in competitive, bid-based markets seek bidding strategies that maximize revenue while accounting for the unique ability of hydropower producers to store energy.
Research_gap: Literature lacked a method for determining a coherent medium-term hydro operations policy in a strategic bidding framework that models price-maker behavior and reservoir inflow uncertainty.
Contribution: A comprehensive literature survey synthesizes modeling approaches for hydropower producers and outlines future research needs for representing non-convexities and exact future revenue functions.

Authors: Fjelldal, B.; Nafstad, S. M.; Klaboe, G.
Title: Optimal day-ahead electricity market bidding considering different ancillary services
Problem_statement: Hydropower producers find it increasingly difficult to decide which regulation markets to enter due to varying physical properties and intertemporal dependencies between markets.
Research_gap: Producers need decision-making tools that can handle multi-market optimization across spot markets and various ancillary service markets like primary and secondary regulation.
Contribution: A deterministic optimization model for day-ahead bidding calculates the lucrative utilization of watercourses by simultaneously considering spot and different regulation markets.

Authors: Sanchez De La Nieta, A. A.; Tavares, T. A. M.; Martins, R. F. M.; Matias, J. C. O.; Catalao, J. P. S.; Contreras, J.
Title: Optimal generic energy storage system offering in day-ahead electricity markets
Problem_statement: Energy storage systems must optimize their charging and discharging behavior to remain profitable within day-ahead electricity markets under price uncertainty.
Research_gap: Existing models often fail to provide detailed information on the behavior of generic storage systems across varying efficiency and marginal cost parameters. (inferred).
Contribution: A stochastic mixed integer linear programming model optimizes offer and purchase bids for a generic energy storage system in the day-ahead market.

Authors: Sanchez De La Nieta, A. A.; Contreras, J.; Munoz, J. I.; Catalao, J. P. S.
Title: Optimal Wind Reversible Hydro Offering Strategies for Midterm Planning
Problem_statement: Wind power uncertainty makes it difficult for producers to maximize profits and minimize imbalances without coordinating offering strategies with flexible storage resources.
Research_gap: There is limited research comparing the midterm effects and profitability of coordinated versus separate offering strategies for wind and reversible hydropower units.
Contribution: A coordinated offering model for wind and reversible hydropower units utilizes CVaR constraints to maximize profits while reducing imbalances compared to separate strategies.

Authors: Li, J.; Liu, J.; Zheng, Y.; Tang, Y.; Hao, W.; Liu, J.
Title: Optimization Operation Model of Wind-PV-hydro-Thermal Integrated System in the Carbon Electricity Market
Problem_statement: Integrating renewable energy sources into spot markets requires new mechanisms to coordinate carbon trading quotas with power supply to meet environmental regulations.
Research_gap: Current spot market models lack integrated multi-stage optimization frameworks that simultaneously handle carbon electricity trading for wind, PV, and hydropower sources. (inferred).
Contribution: A multi-stage optimization model maximizes system revenue by coordinating carbon trading quotas and renewable energy generation under various operational and emission constraints.

Authors: Mohammadi, S.; Khodadadi, A.; Shinde, P.; Blom, E.; Hesamzadeh, M. R.; Söder, L.
Title: Probabilistic Multi-Product Trading of Hydro Power Plants in Sequential Intraday and Frequency-Regulation Markets
Problem_statement: Strategic hydropower producers need to maximize expected profits across day-ahead, frequency containment reserve, and intraday markets while accounting for complex hydrological balance and network transfer limits.
Research_gap: Existing bilevel models lacked an integrated MILP formulation that simultaneously optimizes strategic bidding for energy and reserve markets while considering reservoir content limits and water flow constraints. (inferred).
Contribution: A bilevel programming model optimizes strategic producer profits in multi-market settings by balancing water conservation against revenue maximization through a new mixed-integer linear programming framework.

Authors: Tang, Y.; Liu, Y.; Huo, W.; Chen, M.; Guo, Y.; Wu, W.
Title: Profitability Analysis of Generators in Energy and Ancillary Service Joint Procurement
Problem_statement: Increased renewable penetration creates challenges such as insufficient operational flexibility and deficit profits for conventional suppliers in electricity markets.
Research_gap: There is a lack of joint clearing models that analyze how prices are determined by bids and opportunity costs across multiple market products.
Contribution: A joint clearing model optimizes energy, spinning reserve, and regulation capacity while exploring the cost recovery property for various market participants.

Authors: Kumar, R.; Kumar, A.
Title: Real and Reactive Power Pricing with Hydro Condenser in Pool Based Electricity Market Model
Problem_statement: Maintaining real and reactive power balance at system buses is essential for grid stability, requiring precise injection modeling for varied generation technologies.
Research_gap: Simplified load flow models often ignore reactive power flow and bus voltage injections, leading to inaccurate representations of hydrothermal system operational costs. (inferred).
Contribution: A power flow model uses bus-level injection equations and cost functions to optimize the real and reactive power balance in integrated power grids.

Authors: Skytte, K.; Olsen, O. J.
Title: Regulatory barriers for flexible coupling of the Nordic power and district heating markets
Problem_statement: Outdated policies and regulatory frameworks create barriers that prevent the effective use of district heating as a flexibility resource for integrating wind energy.
Research_gap: Existing research lacks a detailed investigation of the barriers preventing the substitution of heat-only boilers with flexible combined heat and power plants in Denmark.
Contribution: A survey paper identifies regulatory and economic barriers to using district heating for electricity market flexibility and provides recommendations for policy reform.

Authors: Cleto, J.; Simoes, S.; Fortes, P.; Seixas, J.
Title: Renewable energy sources availability under climate change scenarios — Impacts on the Portuguese energy system
Problem_statement: Energy systems must be designed to satisfy demand at the lowest possible cost while adhering to strict environmental policy constraints and emission limits.
Research_gap: There is a need for integrated models that can jointly evaluate installed capacity, primary energy flows, and final prices under varied technology subsidy scenarios. (inferred).
Contribution: The TIMES_PT optimization model determines the lowest-cost combination of energy supply and demand technologies while satisfying primary energy and material flow constraints.

Authors: Su, L.; Nan, H.; Yu, X.; Wu, L.; Li, N.
Title: Research on the Cost Analysis System of Hydropower Ancillary Services Based on LabVIEW
Problem_statement: Efficient and fair cost allocation for spinning reserves is critical in maintaining system reliability within competitive electricity market environments. (inferred).
Research_gap: Existing scientific literature requires improved methodologies for allocating the costs of ancillary services like spinning reserves to market participants. (inferred).
Contribution: A novel method for the cost allocation of spinning reserves improves fairness and efficiency within an electricity market environment. (inferred).

Authors: Conejo, A.; Arroyo, J.; Contreras, J.; Villamor, F.
Title: Self-scheduling of a hydro producer in a pool-based electricity market
Problem_statement: Hydropower companies with cascaded plants must optimize daily self-scheduling to maximize profits while respecting complex spatial-temporal coupling and reservoir head dependencies.
Research_gap: Previous self-scheduling models often ignored the nonlinear dependence between head, discharge, and power, or failed to precisely model start-up wear and tear costs.
Contribution: A 0/1 mixed-integer linear programming model incorporates discretized Hill charts to accurately account for head variations and turbine start-up costs.

Authors: Cerjan, M.; Marcic, D.; Delimar, M.
Title: Short term power system planning with water value and energy trade optimisation
Problem_statement: Optimal hydro scheduling in real systems must account for technical characteristics and socio-economic limitations while accurately forecasting electricity consumption to maintain reservoir levels and water values.
Research_gap: Practical models lacked an integrated visual framework to correlate planned reservoir levels, inflows, and water values against EPEX prices for efficient short-term generation and exchange scheduling. (inferred).
Contribution: A scheduling model integrates short-term load forecasting and technical system parameters to optimize reservoir levels and water values relative to market consumption and exchange demands.

Authors: Xiaoyun, H.; Andi, H.; Jingpeng, S.
Title: Short-term Hydro Power Scheduling under the Electricity Market Environment
Problem_statement: Pump-storage hydropower generators need a practical tool for scheduling and bidding in deregulated electricity markets to stay optimal as new information on prices or inflows arrives.
Research_gap: The field lacked a practical, hourly scheduling method for pump-storage plants that efficiently handles cyclic efficiency and upper reservoir capacity constraints within a weekly planning period. (inferred).
Contribution: A practical scheduling and bidding method for pump-storage hydro plants optimizes weekly generation and total profit based on real data from the European Power Exchange.

Authors: Fosso, O.; Belsnes, M.
Title: Short-term hydro scheduling in a liberalized power system
Problem_statement: Systems with significant reservoir storage require short-term scheduling that is coupled with long-term strategic decisions to ensure consistent and strategic utilization of hydropower resources.
Research_gap: It is computationally infeasible to include detailed online operational constraints in long-term models, necessitating a flexible coupling principle that maintains consistency across a planning hierarchy.
Contribution: A solution based on successive linear programming proposes a flexible coupling principle between mid-term scheduling and detailed short-term models for large hydropower systems.

Authors: Eusebio, E.; Camus, C.; Mendes, V.
Title: Short-term value for the water stored in head-sensitivity power system reservoirs
Problem_statement: Pure linear approaches fail to capture the economic value of water in head-sensitive reservoirs with small storage capacities where hydro plant efficiency is heavily dependent on water level.
Research_gap: Deterministic approaches lacked a quadratic programming formulation to obtain water values from Lagrange multipliers that specifically account for head-sensitivity in tree-cascaded reservoir configurations. (inferred).
Contribution: A deterministic approach using quadratic programming computes short-term water values for head-sensitive reservoirs, emphasizing the role of stored water as a scarce resource with sensitivity-derived economic value.

Authors: Belsnes, M. M.; Warland, G.; Wolfgang, O.
Title: Simulating equilibrium prices in oligopoly power markets
Problem_statement: Exercise of market power in hydropower systems is difficult to reveal because the supply-side resource is inherently stochastic and transmission bottlenecks can create localized price distortions.
Research_gap: Market simulators lacked an extension capable of evaluating price establishment in systems using zonal pricing where transmission limits often prevent treating the power market as a single area. (inferred).
Contribution: A method for simulating price establishment in zonal pricing systems uses a discrete staircase-type bidding approach to evaluate market power and efficiency in the NordPool system.

Authors: Dong, X.; Hu, T.; Li, X.
Title: Simulating Power Supplier's Behavior in Electricity Market
Problem_statement: Electricity markets are often oligopolistic where strategic bidding by power suppliers affects price stability and increases market design risks.
Research_gap: Standard models of perfect rationality are too strict to accurately describe the bounded rationality and learning processes of power suppliers.
Contribution: A simulation model using game learning theory describes the learning behavior of bounded rationality agents to test electricity market designs.

Authors: Forouzandehmehr, N.; Han, Z.; Zheng, R.
Title: Stochastic Dynamic Game between Hydropower Plant and Thermal Power Plant in Smart Grid Networks
Problem_statement: Increasing demand for pollution-free energy requires energy storage to balance supply and demand and mitigate uncertainties in the electricity market.
Research_gap: Standard power system studies lacked an evaluation of the interaction between thermal plants and large-scale pumped-storage hydropower plants using stochastic differential game theory (inferred).
Contribution: A survey of game-theoretic methods and smart grid efforts identifies the role of pumped-storage hydropower plants in balancing market supply and demand.

Authors: Abgottspon, H.; Andersson, G.
Title: Stochastic scheduling for a price-maker hydro producer considering forward trading
Problem_statement: Price-maker hydro producers with pumping capabilities face computational intractability when trying to solve strategic self-scheduling problems involving hourly bidding and forward contracts over a one-year horizon.
Research_gap: Previous self-scheduling models lacked a multi-stage stochastic program that assumes linear price-amount dependencies to remain tractable while calculating water values and optimal forward contract bids. (inferred).
Contribution: A multi-stage stochastic programming model solves the bidding problem for price-maker hydro plants by estimating water values and profits through integrated hourly recourse actions and forward contracts.

Authors: Moiseeva, E.; Hesamzadeh, M. R.
Title: Strategic bidding by a risk-averse firm with a portfolio of renewable resources
Problem_statement: Strategic firms owning flexible renewable resources like hydropower and storage can potentially abuse market power by withholding ramp-rates to manipulate electricity prices during periods of uncertainty.
Research_gap: Existing MPEC models need extension to stochastic setups that consider risk-aversion through CVaR and model the effects of withholding ramp-rate on social welfare and profits.
Contribution: A bi-level stochastic MPEC recast as a single-stage MILP investigates the effect of strategic ramp-rate bidding by risk-averse companies owning varied renewable portfolios.

Authors: Campos, F. A.; Munoz San Roque, A.; Sanchez-Ubeda, E. F.; Portela Gonzalez, J.
Title: Strategic Bidding in Secondary Reserve Markets
Problem_statement: Companies face technical and financial risks when preparing step-wise secondary reserve bidding curves in the very short term under significant market uncertainty.
Research_gap: Related literature often fails to consider different power limits for regulating plants, which can lead to bidding curves that cause significant profit losses.
Contribution: A mixed-integer programming model computes robust secondary reserve bidding curves by considering technical constraints and Multilayer Perceptron-based residual demand curve forecasts.

Authors: Abgottspon, H.; Andersson, G.
Title: Strategic bidding of ancillary services for a hydro power producer
Problem_statement: Agents in secondary control power markets must repeatedly adjust bids based on shared knowledge and water values to optimize expected profits across thousands of game rounds.
Research_gap: The secondary control market lacked an iterative algorithm that shares repetitive knowledge among agents to converge on optimal bids while accounting for specific water values and plant characteristics. (inferred).
Contribution: An iterative parallel algorithm uses shared knowledge and CPLEX to calculate optimal secondary control power bids for agents based on carefully estimated water values and profit functions.

Authors: Alnaes, E. N.; Grondahl, R.; Fleten, S.; Boomsma, T. K.
Title: The degree of rationality in actual bidding of hydropower at Nord Pool
Problem_statement: Flexible hydropower producers often exhibit sub-optimal bidding behavior in day-ahead markets due to complex regulations on water flows and variable fees.
Research_gap: Empirical analysis of individual producer bidding behavior is scarce compared to normative optimization approaches or studies focused solely on market power abuse.
Contribution: An empirical study analyzes actual day-ahead bids to identify underlying factors and quantifies the maximum potential income increase for flexible hydropower producers.

Authors: Pereira, J. P.; Pesquita, V.; Rodrigues, P. M. M.
Title: The effect of hydro and wind generation on the mean and volatility of electricity prices in Spain
Problem_statement: The increasing penetration of wind and solar capacity, alongside variable reservoir levels, creates potential structural breaks in how renewables influence electricity spot-market price level and variance.
Research_gap: Empirical evidence is needed to determine the specific stabilizing effect of reservoir levels on intraday power prices when facing significant wind forecast errors in large systems.
Contribution: An ARX-GARCHX model estimates the impact of wind generation and hydro reservoir levels on Spanish day-ahead prices across different sub-periods and structural breaks.

Authors: Aigner, T.; Jaehnert, S.; Doorman, G. L.; Gjengedal, T.
Title: The Effect of Large-Scale Wind Power on System Balancing in Northern Europe
Problem_statement: Integrating large-scale wind power requires additional regulating reserves and higher flexibility from thermal plants to compensate for production deviations and prediction errors at any instance.
Research_gap: Market participants need a better understanding of how procuring and activating regulating reserves in real-time affects the overall efficiency of liberalized northern European power markets (inferred).
Contribution: A modeling framework analyzes integrated regulating power markets in Europe to evaluate the benefits of transmission capacity reservation for exchanging regulating resources under wind uncertainty.

Authors: Hankimaa, H.; Oliveira, F.; Fanzeres, B.
Title: The Effect of Multi-Market Participation on Day-Ahead Trading of an Electricity Producer
Problem_statement: Power generating companies with hybrid portfolios of dispatchable and renewable energy must manage significant revenue risks from imbalances across sequential electricity markets.
Research_gap: Existing models that constrain expected imbalances to zero are often unsuitable for portfolios containing variable renewable energy generators due to inherent uncertainty.
Contribution: A stochastic optimization model uses a multistage scenario tree to decide optimal offer curves for day-ahead and reserve markets while managing imbalances.

Authors: Nacken, L.; Mobius, T.
Title: The effects of harmonized European climate policy targets in comparison to national targets utilizing a European electricity market model
Problem_statement: Inefficiencies in achieving climate policy targets occur when nations have different marginal generation costs for renewables and emission abatement.
Research_gap: There is a lack of analysis comparing fully harmonized EU-wide climate goals against decentralized, country-specific renewable and emission targets. (inferred).
Contribution: A fundamental electricity market investment and dispatch model evaluates the economic efficiency and electricity price impacts of harmonized European climate targets.

Authors: Eriksen, M.; Trondal, M. E.
Title: The Influence on Day-Ahead Trading Volumes by Including Power Flow Equations in The Planning Algorithm for Short-Term Hydropower in Congested Areas
Problem_statement: Increasing penetration of renewable sources creates bottlenecks and price differences between zones, requiring tools that explicitly model meshed network topology.
Research_gap: Previous short-term hydropower scheduling studies have investigated grid issues in a simplified radial manner, neglecting the complex dynamics of meshed networks.
Contribution: A multi-period optimal power flow algorithm combined with short-term hydropower scheduling evaluates how storage dynamics and grid restrictions influence nodal area prices.

Authors: Vardanyan, Y.; Amelin, M.
Title: The state-of-the-art of the short term hydro power planning with large amount of wind power in the system
Problem_statement: Large-scale introduction of wind power introduces significant variations and uncertainties into the power market, requiring advanced hydropower planning techniques to provide flexibility.
Research_gap: Existing stochastic models for short-term hydropower planning typically reflect only one type of uncertainty rather than addressing multiple types, such as market prices and inflows, simultaneously.
Contribution: A state-of-the-art review categorizes short-term hydropower planning models and identifies the need for multi-stage stochastic models that incorporate multiple types of uncertainty.

Authors: Kjetsa, E. S.; Kjetsa, E. S.; Mo, B.
Title: The value of considering uncertain fuel prices in the profitability evaluation of future HVDC links between the Nordic system and continental Europe
Problem_statement: Hydropower scheduling optimization traditionally assumes fuel prices are deterministic, failing to find strategies that are robust with respect to significant fuel price variations.
Research_gap: Standard stochastic dynamic programming (then "SDP") solution methods are limited by the curse of dimensionality, restricting the state variables available for price modeling in market clearing problems.
Contribution: A theoretical modeling approach includes fuel price uncertainties in water value calculations to increase the benefit of interconnections and shift energy trade to more beneficial times.

Authors: Farinosi, F.; Carrera, L.; Mysiak, J.; Breil, M.; Testella, F.
Title: Tradable certificates for renewable energy: The Italian experience with hydropower
Problem_statement: Sustainable water management in Europe requires effective economic policy instruments to mitigate the hydrologic impacts of hydropower stations and other carbon-neutral energy developments.
Research_gap: Comprehensive documentation and assessment of subsidies for ecologically friendly hydropower plants and the resulting consequences for basin-level water balance are missing from cross-border policy analysis (inferred).
Contribution: The EPI-WATER project report synthesizes case studies on Italian and German renewable certificates and subsidies to evaluate their effectiveness for sustainable water and energy management.

Authors: Toma, L.; Urluescu, L.; Eremia, M.; Revaz, J.
Title: Trading Ancillary Services for Frequency Regulation in Competitive Electricity Markets
Problem_statement: Transmission system operators must define clear technical codes and operational procedures for qualifying suppliers of balancing energies and ancillary services. (inferred).
Research_gap: Methodological voids exist regarding the selection and qualification processes for different types of balancing energies in national transmission networks. (inferred).
Contribution: A set of operational procedures and technical codes defines the qualification and selection criteria for ancillary service providers in a power system. (inferred).

Authors: Braun, S. M.; Burkhardt, M.
Title: Trading of pumped storage hydropower plants on energy only and ancillary services markets
Problem_statement: Hydropower storage operators must maximize profits by coordinating turbine and pump use across different electricity market stages and target reservoir levels. (inferred).
Research_gap: Methodologies for optimizing hydroelectric systems under spot and control energy market prices require more comprehensive stochastic representations. (inferred).
Contribution: A profit maximization model for hydropower systems optimizes turbine and pump operations using market prices and reservoir filling levels. (inferred).

Authors: Duc, D. X.; Singh, J. G.; Ongsakul, W.
Title: Water valuation in Vietnamese electric power generation market
Problem_statement: Managing saved water for future use in hydro-thermal systems requires substantially accurate water value calculations that can account for transmission constraints and stochastic inflow variables.
Research_gap: Systems modeling lacked a solution algorithm that effectively applies stochastic dual dynamic programming to large-scale hydro-thermal optimization while maintaining technical and transmission accuracy. (inferred).
Contribution: This work suggests using the SDDP method as a solution algorithm to execute substantial water value calculations and optimize stochastic hydro-thermal power systems with transmission constraints.

Authors: Helseth, A.; Mo, B.; Fodstad, M.
Title: Water values in future power markets
Problem_statement: Hydropower valuation is significantly affected when considering multiple balancing markets, yet including all reserve capacity and energy markets in weekly scheduling models is an exhaustive computational task.
Research_gap: Scheduling models lacked a framework to find how water valuation is precisely affected by the inclusion of reserve capacity procurement and balancing energy within a multi-market setting. (inferred).
Contribution: A multi-market scheduling model evaluates how the valuation of water is affected by balancing markets, considering uncertainties in inflows and prices over three to five-year analysis periods.

Authors: Figueiredo, N. C.; Pereira Da Silva, P.; Cerqueira, P.
Title: Wind generation influence on market splitting: The Iberian spot electricity market
Problem_statement: High deployment of wind and hydropower can create grid congestion and market splitting, challenging the management of cross-border interconnections.
Research_gap: Previously used parametric models have known limitations and fail to provide sufficient detail on market splitting probability responses.
Contribution: Non-parametric models express the probability of market splitting as a function of wind power, hydropower, available transmission capacity, and demand.

Authors: Aminabadi, M. J.; Séguin, S.; Fleten, S.; Aasgård, E. K.
Title: Optimizing Profile Block Bids in Short-Term Hydropower Scheduling: A Two-Phase Model for the Day-Ahead Market
Problem_statement: Producers with cascaded reservoirs must navigate complex intertemporal dependencies and conflicts between upstream and downstream water releases when bidding in day-ahead markets.
Research_gap: While regular block bidding is well-researched, there is a lack of contributions addressing profiled block bids for Norwegian day-ahead market participation.
Contribution: A two-phase optimization model generates feasible production profiles and then selects the most profitable blocks using a two-stage linear stochastic program.

Authors: Shawwash, Z.; Siu, T.; Russell, S.
Title: The B.C. Hydro short term hydro scheduling optimization model
Problem_statement: System operators in competitive markets need to secure sufficient energy and capacity while exploiting system flexibility and managing financial risks in real-time power supply operations.
Research_gap: Operators often do not accept the simplifications in abstract optimization models or find them difficult to use within the time constraints of real-time scheduling.
Contribution: A fast and flexible decision support system, STOM, uses linear programming to determine the optimal tradeoff between long-term water value and real-time spot trading returns.

Authors: Liu, J.; Chen, H.; Yin, X.
Title: The Sequential Clearing Mechanism of Energy Market and Regulating Ancillary Service Market Including Pumped Storage
Problem_statement: Immature market-oriented incentive mechanisms for pumped storage units to participate in frequency modulation diminish the willingness of pumped storage units to participate in stabilizing power grids.
Research_gap: Electricity markets need sequential clearing mechanisms that effectively integrate pumped storage units into both energy and regulating ancillary service markets simultaneously (inferred).
Contribution: A sequential clearing mechanism for the day-ahead market optimizes pumped storage participation in energy and ancillary service markets while considering technical limits and efficiency.

Authors: Klaboe, G.; Fosso, O. B.
Title: Optimal bidding in sequential physical markets: A literature review and framework discussion
Problem_statement: The growth of markets with shorter time horizons than the day-ahead market raises questions about coordinating bids to maximize profit across sequential stages.
Research_gap: There is a lack of a systematic framework for consistency in modeling volume-price relationships and competition assumptions across sequential electricity markets.
Contribution: A literature review and framework discussion identifies four critical issues for sequential market modeling, ensuring consistent assumptions across turnover volumes and prices.

Authors: Lipp, K.; Egerer, J.
Title: The flexibility of hydroelectric reservoir and pumped storage generation: Application to Switzerland
Problem_statement: Increasing fluctuating renewable generation requires greater power system flexibility, yet system-wide market models often use simplified representations that ignore hydropower storage technical constraints.
Research_gap: Existing models exhaustively study constraints at the level of individual plants but lack a detailed system-wide representation that accounts for hydraulic interconnections and seasonal inflows.
Contribution: A detailed techno-economic optimization model accounts for hydraulic interconnections and plant capacity constraints to optimize the hourly dispatch of Swiss hydropower assets.

Authors: Xu, B.; Zhong, P.; Wu, Y.; Fu, F.; Chen, Y.; Zhao, Y.
Title: A Multiobjective Stochastic Programming Model for Hydropower Hedging Operations under Inexact Information
Problem_statement: Uncertain inflows and inexact penalizing price information create risks of energy shortfall for hydropower companies, potentially leading to significant economic losses and contract violations.
Research_gap: Standard hedging models lack a unified structure that integrates multiobjective tradeoffs between direct revenue maximization and energy shortfall minimization under interval-parameter uncertainty.
Contribution: A multiobjective multistage stochastic programming model uses shadow price analysis and parameter sensitivity tests to rationalize hedging decisions for the Three Gorges cascade system.

Authors: Helseth, A.; Fodstad, M.; Askeland, M.; Mo, B.; Nilsen, O. B.; Pérez‐Díaz, J. I.; Chazarra, M.; Guisández, I.
Title: Assessing hydropower operational profitability considering energy and reserve markets
Problem_statement: Traditional linear models for long-term scheduling often overestimate operational profitability because they fail to represent non-convex system characteristics and opportunities in reserve capacity markets.
Research_gap: The hydropower literature lacked an SDP-based decomposition model that benchmarks linear scheduling policies and quantifies approximation errors while accounting for energy and reserve market interactions. (inferred).
Contribution: A stochastic dynamic programming model allows for non-convex system representation and demonstrates that linear approximations significantly overestimate operational profitability when reserve capacity markets are ignored.

Authors: Tilmant, A.; Pinte, D.; Goor, Q.
Title: Assessing marginal water values in multipurpose multireservoir systems via stochastic programming
Problem_statement: Water managers in arid regions face complex trade-offs when allocating limited water across hydropower and irrigation sectors under highly stochastic hydrologic conditions.
Research_gap: Most nonmarket valuation studies focus on long-run policies and assume water availability is fixed, ignoring the stochasticity required for operational short-run allocation.
Contribution: A stochastic dual dynamic programming approach assesses the statistical distribution of marginal water values in multipurpose systems by using Lagrange multipliers as shadow prices.

Authors: Trondsen, B. J.; Steen, O. M. H.; Sheppard, A. J.
Title: Assessing Operational Behaviour of a Hybrid Hydro-Solar Power Plant Providing Security of Supply Under Weather Uncertainty in the Nordics
Problem_statement: Integrating high proportions of clean energy requires advanced forecasting and uncertainty modeling techniques to maintain the stability and efficiency of long and short-term power supply.
Research_gap: The energy sector lacked a comprehensive review that synthesizes uncertainty modeling techniques specifically for power systems integrating variable clean energy sources and reservoir statistics. (inferred).
Contribution: This review synthesizes advanced uncertainty modeling and time-series analysis techniques to improve long and short-term power supply forecasting under clean energy integration.

Authors: Arsenault, R.; Côté, P.; Latraverse, M.
Title: Assessing the Impacts of Integrating Snowpack Error Distribution in the Management of a Hydropower Reservoir Using Bayesian Stochastic Dynamic Programming (BSDP)
Problem_statement: Hydrological variables used in reservoir management, such as soil humidity and precipitation, are subject to significant measurement bias and seasonal error distributions.
Research_gap: Standard management techniques often lack a method to naturally correct hydrologic bias or represent the uncertainty of snowpack errors in a way that avoids flooding (inferred).
Contribution: A Bayesian stochastic dynamic programming (then "SDP") tool integrates snowpack error distributions to improve uncertainty representation and naturally correct hydrological variable bias in hydropower reservoir management.

Authors: Davis, M. D.; Lund, J. R.; Howitt, R. E.
Title: Banking Groundwater to Meet Growing Water Demand in California
Problem_statement: Analyzing California's future water supply requires evaluating price allocation versus current operation policies under promising conjunctive use and cooperative operations.
Research_gap: Existing models had a limited ability to represent water quality, fixed urban pumping costs, or the interactions between individual underground reservoir subbasins in statewide versions.
Contribution: The CALVIN economic optimization model provides a statewide framework to evaluate the economic benefits of policy alternatives and the willingness-to-pay for additional water reliability.

Authors: Mo, B.; Martino, S.; Naversen, C.; Aronsen, G.; Rismark, O.
Title: Benchmarking Hydro Operation by Use of a Simulator

Authors: Kleiven, A.; Risanger, S.; Fleten, S.
Title: Co-movements between forward prices and resource availability in hydro-dominated electricity markets
Problem_statement: Simplistic modeling using fixed correlation coefficients fails to capture the sophisticated dependencies between electricity prices and reservoir inflows that vary dynamically throughout the year.
Research_gap: Research lacked analytical insights into the intuition behind co-movements and a sophisticated price process to characterize their actual impact on policy in a multistage setting.
Contribution: A novel stochastic model uses MC-SDDP to characterize the impact of co-movements between prices and inflows, demonstrating that ignoring correlations incurs only modest economic losses in practice.

Authors: Aasgård, E. K.
Title: Coordinated Hydropower Bidding in the Day-Ahead and Balancing Market
Problem_statement: Hydropower producers often exhibit sub-optimal bidding behavior in day-ahead markets by failing to account for all marginal and opportunity costs.
Research_gap: There is a lack of empirical analysis documenting how actual bids submitted by reservoir hydropower producers deviate from rational optimization benchmarks.
